Thanks Beth - that's an interesting conclusion.
I suppose that would imply =
that there may also be a level of trust which people apply to what they hea=
r, that maybe isn't justified?

And I'll make the next timeframe shorter=C2=

xperiment even though none of us got the right answer.  I was thinking abou=

spirits of people.. hopefully... and they have the same limitations I do.  =
They are just people, so they cannot know everything that is everywhere.  T=
hey are not like God who is all seeing and all knowing.  I don't know that =
we could ever get this answer right.



I still enjoyed doing it though, an=
d I couldn't wait to see what the picture was.  Lol, I didn't think Wed. wo=
uld ever get here!



Beth

  You say that David gave you

ear it, or would not accept it,

uld sound like a  frustrating situation

 experiment could in theory help there, by

 when you have heard a valid message, versus when

r own prejudices into the sound (as in this  case, you

ills  through these experiments) and to David (as he would not have

  are coming through all the

> In a message  dated 7/14/2010 6:27:09 P=
.M. Eastern Daylight Time,  

> rasterer@yahoo. com writes:

> 

>  

> I t=
hink it does matter though.  

> 

> One of the things we're trying to do i=
s set  up an objective framework for 

> experimenting with  some of these =
aspects.  I think we have all  experienced 

> the difficulty in hearing wh=
at is on  some of these recordings: sometimes 

> we're not sure  at first =
what it says. Sometimes we ask others for  their 

> input.  Sometimes we o=
nly hear it once  someone else tells us it first.  

> Sometimes we  hear i=
t wrong.  Sometimes we hear it right. And  so on.

> 

> It would be useful=
 to know, as an  individual, how good we are at hearing 

> it right, so  w=
e have some idea how trustworthy our skill, or  methods, or 

> technology,=
 is.  If we can measure  that, or even get a feel for it, we can 

> look f=
or  ways to improve it.  If we can't measure it,  then we could be 

> stuc=
k.  

> 

> So, by  restricting the answers only to the timeframe of the  e=
xperiment, 

> we can help filter out some of the  problems of subjectivity=
: for example, 

> one theory is  that people can hear what they want to he=
ar, or can  these 

> sounds in a certain way, once you already know  the a=
nswer.  Or, given 2 ways to 

> hear a sound,  being influenced, even subco=
nsciously, to hear it  one way 

> over the other.  We want to rule that  o=
ut.

> 

> This is one reason we can only count on  answers given during th=
e 

> timeframe.  That is  when the answer is most objective.  Once the  ob=
ject has been 

> announced, we move into a   period where we can't discoun=
t possible influence  

> from already knowing the answer.

> 

> But, I am=
  confident that if a person's method or technology  really can 

> reveal =
the correct answer outside the  timeframe, then doing it within the 

> tim=
eframe should  be just as easy, and would then be a valid objective  result=
 

> for all to see.

>

il it", or a host of other  reasons.

ctive as possible, only answers sent during

> Thanks again for ev=
eryone who  participated! I admire your courage and  

> motivation to try =
different methods, see what  works, and try to improve 

> everyone's  unde=
rstanding of EVP-ITC.

> 

> If you recall,  on 7/10/2010 I placed an objec=
t on top of my  computer 

> monitor, right in front of me, and left  it th=
ere until today, 7/14/2010, noon 

> Denver  time. The experiment was for p=
articipants to  determine what it was. 

> Vague or partial answers  wouldn=
't be counted (for example, just colors,  

> shapes, sizes, what it's made=
 of, etc): we're  looking for what it is. 

> Participants could use  their=
 ghost boxes, EVP recorders, or I suppose  any other 

> means they chose.
=

> 

> In order to  keep me honest, I took a picture of the object  at the =
start 

> of the experiment and loaded it to  the Files section (RJ folder)=
 of this 

> group. If  you can follow the link, it is here:

> 

> _http:/=
/tech.  groups.yahoo. com/group/ EVP-ITC/files/  RJ/RJ.20100710. 

> 1.zip_=
 (http://tech.groups.yahoo.com/group/EVP-ITC/files/RJ/RJ.20100710.1.zip) 

=
> 

> The idea was  that you could download the file at the  beginning of t=
he 

> test, and 'keep it safe' on  your computer. Then at the end of the t=
est, I  

> would release the password so you could reveal  the contents of=
 the file. That 

> way, you were in  control of the original image during =
the entire  test, not 

> me. 

> 

> The password for that file  is: 123Bl=
astOff

> Instructions, if you need  them, are also in that RJ folder.

> 
=

> And if  you did not care to download the zip file before  the test, I wi=
ll 

> post the final image there  too.

> 

> So to the results:

> 

> Nu=
mber of  participants: 5

> Total tries: 8

> Ambiguous  answers: 0

> Corr=
ect answers: 0

> 

> Object:  A radio

> Uzipped picture:

> _http://tech.=
  groups.yahoo. com/group/ EVP-ITC/files/  RJ/RJ.20100710. 

> 1.JPG_ (http=
://tech.groups.yahoo.com/group/EVP-ITC/files/RJ/RJ.20100710.1.JPG) 

> 

> =
So what do the  results mean? All that we can really agree on  from this 

=
> experiment is that no participant,  with whatever theories or methods or =


> technology  they used, was able to correctly determine the  object. We =
can't say 

> those theories or methods  or technologies never work. Just a=
s we can't say  

> they do. Just that, for whatever reason, they  did not =
work this time. 

> Readers can take the  results, use them to improve or c=
hange their  methods, or 

> keep doing what they're  doing.

> 

> If anyo=
ne has any observations,  comments, or ideas for improvement, let me 

> kn=
ow.  I hope to get a new experiment up and running  soon. Since there 

> w=
asn't much participation  Mon-Wed, I think the next experiment will be  

>=
 arranged to mostly span the  weekends.

> 

> Again, thanks to everyone wh=
o  participated in this first  experiment.

>
